Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Multi-Scale Approaches to Quantify Biomechanical Control of Lymphatic Pump Function

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to investigate ways in which the coordination of the lymphatic pump is self-regulated such that transient changes in vessel mechanical loading provide a cue to orchestrate the contractile sequences in adjacent vessel segments. Lymphatic muscle cells contract the vessel to move fluid form the interstitium against a pressure gradient. It is unclear how biomechanics regulate the timing and function of lymphatic contraction across short time scales. The objective will be addressed by performing a system identification of the primary lymphatic contractile unit in order to characterize the pump function response to the variety of biomechanical conditions experienced in the body. The experiments will seek to demonstrate that these phenomena are driven by calcium signaling and regulated in part via release of endothelin-1 and nitric oxide within the vessel. These hypotheses will be tested across multiple length scales using in-vitro biomechanical tissue culture devices, feedback-controlled isolated vessel perfusion systems, and in-vivo near infrared (NIR) imaging.

Understanding how lymphatic biology utilizes biomechanics to regulate and coordinate its drainage response to varying demands will not only provide key insight into diseases such as lymphedema, but it will also provide bio-inspired design approaches for developing artificial drainage networks in tissue engineering and nanotechnology that function in an as-needed fashion. The educational plan for this award seeks to address the current disparity in lymphatic training and research. Teaching modules on lymphatic physiology will be implemented at a nearby medical school and research results will be integrated into a graduate level Biotransport course to provide students with unsolved engineering problems in lymphatic biomechanics through problem-based learning. Lastly, elementary students will be engaged in interactive research-based science education, where they will be exposed to the impact of bioengineering approaches in medicine.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Biomechanics is foundational to the organization and function of all tissues in the body. However, the roll of biomechanics on the lymphatic system function has remained largely unexplored. In this CAREER award project, the fundamental roll of biomechanical forces on lymphatic pump coordination was explored in cell culture models, in tissues, and in animal models. Specifically, it was discovered that the force on the lymphatic endothelial cells lining the endothelial wall played a major role in regulating the contractile behavior of lymphatic vessels. Experimental evidence was generated to show that the dynamically varying nature of this fluid force was sufficient to entrain the contraction with the fluid flow. In other words, multiple contracting units in series could coordinate the timing of their contractions through an auto regulation mechanism that is driven by fluid shear stress. 

The work went on to show that the mechanism of this coordination depends on the applied magnitude of the fluid force, the unique sensitivity of each vessel to the fluid force, the intrinsic frequency of contraction of each vessel, and the frequency of the externally applied flow waveform. There have been several recent publications in the field of computational modeling of lymphatic flows that have postulated that mechanosensitive feedback could coordinate and control lymphatic pump function, however the work done here was the first to ever experimentally show dynamic coordination of lymphatic contractility as a result of feedback from the mechanosensation of fluid flow.   This observation not only was fundamental to our understanding of mechanobiology in lymphatics, but it led to the unique discovery that the modulation of lymphatic function via the application of external message, exhibit similar frequency dependent behavior on vessel entrainment. Specifically, there was an ideal spatial and temporal frequency range for which externally applied pressure would enhance contractile entrainment. 

Finally, the project supported many unique opportunities for promoting the educational development of future scientists and for promoting enhancement of lymphatic education amongst medical professionals. There is a significant disparity in our understanding of how the lymphatic system functions, a fact which is reflected in the very minimal time spent on covering the lymphatic system in medical school. Several educational modules on lymphatics were developed as part of this award and were delivered at physician intensive trainings for continuing education credit, at grand rounds for medical students in physical therapy, and for residents in plastic surgery. Several educational modules on lymphatic mechanics were also developed for delivery in our core biomechanics courses in both tissue mechanics and biofluid mechanics. Lastly, the project provided opportunities for research support costs for high school students working in the lab through an internal program at Georgia Tech.
